repnme.cdata!: Malawi - Privatization and Utility Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Privatization and
            Utility Reform Project (PURP) for Malawi were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was modest, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: there is a need for consensus on
            privatization issues especially with the policy makers. A
            robust and well targeted public awareness program is
            critical to sustain public support, especially for the
            larger, politically difficult transactions. In the second
            half of the project implementation this aspect was very much
            reinforced leading to a speedier implementation.
            Overestimation of capacity within the Privatization
            Commission (PC) at project design meant that the project did
            not have adequate procurement and financial management
            capacity in the first three years of project life. This
            effectively delayed achievement of project outcomes and
            outputs. For the future it will be important to properly
            assess capacity specific to project requirements. A
            communications strategy that targets all key stakeholders
            and constantly provides all relevant and accurate
            information in a timely matter is critical to the success of
            reforms of this nature. Project design and implementation
            should retain sufficient flexibility to reflect changes in
            context and country priorities. The restructuring of PURP
            allowed the project to remain relevant and use its resources
            to reflect a new stage in private sector programming and development.

9735328.trustfund: TF036039-ECA REGION - ECA BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT,TF036687-GLOBAL - TELECOMMUNICATIONS,TF037721-ECA REGION - TELECOMMUNICATIONS,TF038016-MALAWI - PRIV & UTILITY REF

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Privatization and Utilities Reform
            Project : proposed amendments to the legal agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
The amendment to the Development Credit
            Agreement for the Privatization and Utilities Reform Project
            for Malawi addresses the causes of current slow
            implementation progress, responds to new challenges facing
            the Government of Malawi in parastatal reform, and
            incorporates lessons learned to improve the effectiveness of
            the program. Second it focuses on pre-privatization
            preparatory activities and strengthening of the regulatory
            frameworks for entities already privatized and those
            earmarked for future privatization. Third it reconstitutes
            and strengthens the project Steering Committee, with
            technical oversight delegated to the Ministry of Finance.
            Fourth it reallocates the proceeds of the Credit among
            Disbursement Categories, and increases the disbursement
            percentages to 100 percent for all categories, based on the
            approved country financing parameters for Malawi.

442452.trustfund: TF038016-MALAWI - PRIV & UTILITY REF,TF037721-ECA REGION - TELECOMMUNICATIONS,TF036687-GLOBAL - TELECOMMUNICATIONS,TF036039-ECA REGION - ECA BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT

repnme.cdata!: Malawi - Privatization and Utility Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Privatization and Utility Reform
            Project's objective is to improve the quality of and
            access to economic and physical infrastructure for private
            sector development. The project consists of four components:
            1) The privatization component will support the development
            of divestiture options and/or implementation of the chosen
            divestiture methods for utility divestitures. 2) Support to
            regulatory institutions will enhance the operations of the
            Malawi Communications Regulatory Authority for postal and
            telecommunications regulation and the Electricity for power
            regulation. 3) Postal sector support will support the three
            year business plan of Malawi Posts Corporation in order to
            help the postal service progress towards full cost recovery
            after its separation from the Malawi Telecom Limited (MTL).
            4) Pre-privatization assistance will support restructuring
            activities in Electricity Supply Corporation of Malawi
            Limited including the conducting of a tariff study and
            establishing a financial management system. It will also
            ensure that Year 2000 compliance is achieved in MTL.
